item.title: Claude Code + Backlog.md: Building Git Kanban + AI Collaboration
item.content:encoded:

This article will get you up and running in 5 minutes, covering installation, core features, and typical workflows to explain why it‚Äôs the minimal viable stack for human + AI collaborative projects.

Section titled ‚ÄúIntroduction‚Äù

Tired of switching between multiple SaaS tools? Backlog.md generates a complete project management system locally with a single command‚Äîperfect for individual developers and seamlessly integrates with multi-agent pipelines, allowing Claude and Gemini to directly read and write tasks.

Section titled ‚ÄúI. Why Choose Backlog.md?‚Äù

1. Markdown as Natural Task Cards

Section titled ‚Äú1. Markdown as Natural Task Cards‚Äù
  • Each issue is a task-123 - title.md file, ready for Git diff tracking.
  • Local editors work great, and AI can read them easily.

2. 100% Private & Offline

Section titled ‚Äú2. 100% Private & Offline‚Äù
  • All files live in your repository with no external dependencies; edit your kanban even on a train.

3. Zero-Configuration Kanban

Section titled ‚Äú3. Zero-Configuration Kanban‚Äù
  • backlog board renders live queues directly in the terminal.
  • backlog browser auto-opens a responsive Web UI with drag-and-drop status updates.

Section titled ‚Äú4. AI-Ready CLI‚Äù
  • Includes CLAUDE.md and other documentation files‚Äîjust type ‚ÄúClaude, please take over task-33‚Äù to assign work.
  • Supports sub-agents and Ultrathink planning, compatible with popular models.

5. Cross-Platform + Multiple Installation Channels

Section titled ‚Äú5. Cross-Platform + Multiple Installation Channels‚Äù
  • Choose from npm i -g backlog.md, brew install backlog-md, or nix run.
  • Homebrew & Fedora packages available simultaneously with fast version updates.

Section titled ‚ÄúII. 3-Step Quick Start‚Äù
StepCommandDescription
Initializebacklog init "AI Side Project"Interactive setup, auto-generates backlog/ directory
Create Tasksbacklog task create "Refactor login flow"Supports description, assignee, tags, priority, etc.
View Progressbacklog board or backlog browserTerminal / browser‚Äîtwo flavors

III. Advanced Usage

Section titled ‚ÄúIII. Advanced Usage‚Äù

1. One-Click Weekly Reports

Section titled ‚Äú1. One-Click Weekly Reports‚Äù

Section titled ‚Äú2. Multi-Repository Coordination‚Äù
  • Use git worktree or sub-repositories to aggregate BE/FE tasks into the same directory; all links still point to original branches.

3. Auto-Commit & Hook Bypass

Section titled ‚Äú3. Auto-Commit & Hook Bypass‚Äù
  • backlog config set autoCommit true eliminates manual git add/commit.
  • For strict pre-commit setups, use bypassGitHooks true.

Section titled ‚Äú4. Statistics & Dashboard‚Äù

backlog overview displays task burndown and bar charts in the terminal, giving you instant project health insights.

Section titled ‚ÄúIV. Use Cases‚Äù
  1. Independent Developers: Local Git + Markdown, everything on one machine.
  2. Remote Small Teams: Pull Requests sync task status automatically‚Äîgoodbye Jira.
  3. AI Agent Pipelines: LLMs read/update task files, enabling ‚Äúplanning‚Üícoding‚ÜíPR‚Äù closed loops.

Section titled ‚ÄúConclusion‚Äù

Backlog.md uses the most native toolchain to unify project management, documentation, and AI collaboration into one system, helping us refocus attention on ‚Äúwriting code‚Äù itself.

item.title: Stress-Free Spelling: ChatGPT's 1-Hour Daily Vocabulary Training Plan for 3rd Graders
item.content:encoded:
ChatGPT has designed an English vocabulary spelling training program suitable for 3rd grade primary school students: spending 1 hour daily, combining drawing, games, and parent interaction to primarily address the problems of forgetting spelling and tension during dictation tests, while ensuring a reasonable and effective weekly vocabulary acquisition rate.

Introduction

Section titled ‚ÄúIntroduction‚Äù

Designed for a 3rd grade primary school student‚Äôs English vocabulary spelling needs, we have created a scientifically engaging training program. The student initially planned to master approximately 70 new words per week, but we will make adjustments based on scientific recommendations. The student has 1 hour of practice time daily, with parents available to participate. The child enjoys drawing and games, and currently faces main difficulties in remembering word spelling and experiencing tension during dictation tests. We will explain this program from six aspects: weekly vocabulary quantity, daily practice schedule, memorization techniques, parental assistance methods, games to relieve dictation tension, and weekly review and testing.

I. Scientific Recommendations for Weekly New Vocabulary Quantity

Section titled ‚ÄúI. Scientific Recommendations for Weekly New Vocabulary Quantity‚Äù

Research shows that concentrating on learning 10-12 new words per week yields better results. Too many new words exceed children‚Äôs memory load, leading to increased forgetting rates. Taking China‚Äôs new primary school English curriculum standards as an example, the total vocabulary for primary school is approximately 505 basic words. The new 3rd grade textbook‚Äôs first semester contains 111 words (64 in the old version). At this pace, primary school students need to master only about 5-10 words per week on average.

Scientific recommendation: Adjusting the weekly new vocabulary quantity to around 20-30 words is more reasonable, with flexibility based on the child‚Äôs receptive ability. For example, learning 25 new words per week, approximately 5 per day. This ensures children have sufficient repetition and consolidation opportunities without developing apprehension due to excessive quantity. Quality over quantity‚Äîensuring children truly master each word‚Äôs spelling and usage is more important than merely pursuing numbers.

II. Daily 1-Hour Practice Schedule (Listen, Speak, Read, Write, Play)

Section titled ‚ÄúII. Daily 1-Hour Practice Schedule (Listen, Speak, Read, Write, Play)‚Äù

The daily 1-hour practice requires reasonable allocation of listening, speaking, reading, writing, and playing activities, achieving a balance between movement and stillness, tension and relaxation. Below is a table showing recommended daily practice arrangements:

Time SegmentActivity Content (Skill Focus)Description and Purpose
5 minutesWarm-up and Review (Listen, Speak)Listen to parents read words or phrases from the previous day, with children speaking along with pronunciation. Clapping hands or doing actions while reciting can stimulate interest. Through quick review of learned vocabulary, activate memory and prepare for the day‚Äôs learning.
10 minutesNew Word Introduction (Listen, Speak)Using recordings or parent demonstrations, listen to 3-5 new words‚Äô correct pronunciation and practice reading aloud. Parents can place words in short sentences to read to children, helping understand word meanings. Children primarily develop listening discrimination and oral imitation skills in this segment, initially recognizing new words.
15 minutesRecognition and Comprehension (Read, Speak, Play)Present new word cards or write on a whiteboard, have children read words and state their meanings. Combine with pictures or let children draw small illustrations to deepen visual association memory. Play ‚Äúlittle teacher‚Äù games, having children create sentences or tell small stories with each word, speaking while remembering to enhance understanding. This segment balances reading cognition and oral expression while incorporating game elements.
15 minutesWriting Practice (Write)Have children write new words in notebooks, writing each word three times after dividing into syllables using pinyin or phonetic segmentation. For example, ‚Äúbecause‚Äù divided as be-cause before writing. Use interesting variations like rainbow letter writing (each letter in different colors) or writing letters in sand trays to increase fun. Parents should promptly check writing, correct spelling errors, and guide children to pay attention to letter sequence. Through writing, deepen word spelling memory.
10 minutesFun Word Games (Listen, Read, Write, Play)Use games to consolidate the day‚Äôs learning. Examples: spelling relay games where parents say a word, children write the first letter, parents continue with the second letter, taking turns to spell out words; or play ‚Äúmissing letter‚Äù games: write out words then have children close eyes, parents erase one letter, children open eyes and say which letter is missing. Can also play word puzzles, letter card word spelling, dictation quick-answer, etc. Through games, reinforce spelling in a relaxed atmosphere.
5 minutesQuiz and Feedback (Listen, Write)Parents orally quiz 2-3 new words from the day, asking children to attempt dictation. Try to simulate school dictation format but maintain a relaxed atmosphere. Then check spelling accuracy together. Praise correct writing and avoid criticism for errors; instead, work together with children to sound out and correct. Finally, record with stickers or smiley faces. This segment helps children promptly understand their mastery level, identifying and filling gaps same-day.

The above arrangement totals approximately 60 minutes, with each segment‚Äôs time adjustable based on children‚Äôs attention span. Daily practice covers listening, speaking, reading, writing aspects while interspersing games and rest transitions, ensuring children maintain interest and focus throughout. With parental accompaniment, emphasizing encouragement and interaction, create a pleasant learning atmosphere.

III. Age-Appropriate Spelling Memory Techniques

Section titled ‚ÄúIII. Age-Appropriate Spelling Memory Techniques‚Äù

3rd grade children are at an age of visual thinking and interest-driven learning, so various fun memory techniques can help memorize word spelling. Here are several effective methods:

  • Visual Association Memory: Utilizing children‚Äôs love for drawing, connect words with images for memory. For example, when memorizing ‚Äúelephant,‚Äù have children draw an elephant and mark the letters of ‚Äúelephant‚Äù on the elephant‚Äôs body; seeing the image triggers letter spelling associations. For abstract words, use homophonics or visualization methods, connecting word shapes with familiar objects, like viewing words as pictures. This visual memory activates the brain‚Äôs image memory capabilities, enhancing memory effectiveness.

  • Syllable Breakdown Method: Break long words into readable syllables or phonetic chunks, memorizing section by section. For example, ‚Äúremember‚Äù can be split into ‚Äúre-mem-ber,‚Äù memorizing each section then connecting them for spelling. For multi-syllable words, create sentences to help remember each syllable‚Äôs pronunciation and sequence. For instance, memorizing ‚Äúmammoth‚Äù using the sentence ‚ÄúMy Aunt Mary‚Äôs Manly Hat‚Äù to help remember the mam-moth parts (each word‚Äôs initial letter corresponds to the original word‚Äôs spelling). This breakdown method makes long words ‚Äúshorter,‚Äù reducing memory difficulty.

  • Fun Mnemonics and Initial Letter Aids: Create catchy sentences or mnemonics using word letters‚Äô initials to form memorable phrases. For example, the 7 letters B-E-C-A-U-S-E in ‚Äúbecause‚Äù can correspond to the English phrase: ‚ÄúBig Elephants Can Always Understand Small Elephants.‚Äù Humorous sentences contain each letter‚Äôs beginning while having meaning that‚Äôs easy to remember, allowing children to memorize spelling through fun. Parents can also work with children to create small mnemonics in Chinese or English for easily misspelled words‚Äîthe more visual and interesting, the better.

  • Rhyming Song Memory: Use nursery rhymes or verses to remember word spelling and pronunciation. Incorporate spelling rules into simple songs, or find words with similar ending sounds to recite together. For example, use nursery rhymes to remember the rule ‚Äúletter Q is always followed by U,‚Äù or use alphabet songs for spelling. Rhyming helps children better perceive rhythm and letter patterns. For instance, have children discover rhyming word patterns: mastering ‚Äúball‚Äù spelling makes it easy to remember ‚Äútall, call, fall, hall‚Äù and other rhyming words‚Äô spelling. Using familiar melodies to sing word letters is also a memory method children enjoy.

  • Multi-sensory Memory: Encourage children to use auditory, tactile, and motor participation in vocabulary memorization. For example, clapping or stomping feet while spelling word rhythms; using colored clay to shape word letter forms; tracing letters on paper before attempting dictation; closing eyes and using fingers to write letters in air or palm. These multi-sensory participation methods enhance children‚Äôs muscle memory and sensory memory of letter sequences, making vocabulary memorization more than just static eye and brain activity. Children enjoy hands-on activities, and learning through play creates stronger retention.

In summary, combining images, sounds, rhythm, body movements, and other methods can greatly improve spelling memory efficiency and enjoyment. Parents might work with children to create their own memory techniques, making vocabulary memorization a creative endeavor.

IV. Methods for Parents to Assist Children‚Äôs Learning

Section titled ‚ÄúIV. Methods for Parents to Assist Children‚Äôs Learning‚Äù

Parental companionship and guidance are very important in children‚Äôs vocabulary learning. Parents can adopt the following methods to help children learn efficiently and enjoyably:

  • Participate in Games, Learn Together: Utilizing children‚Äôs love for games, parents can act as game partners. For example, play ‚Äúspelling relay‚Äù or ‚Äúspelling snowman (Hangman adaptation)‚Äù together, making the learning process filled with laughter. Parents can also create reward systems, such as giving children a small sticker or drawing a star for each correct spelling, using game reward mechanisms to stimulate motivation.

  • Read Words Aloud, Guide Pronunciation: Parents should daily accompany children in reading aloud word lists or example sentences, providing correct pronunciation demonstrations. When children spell, patiently listen and promptly correct pronunciation and spelling errors. Use syllable-by-syllable spelling methods and encourage children to boldly speak and imitate. Through parent-child reading, children practice listening and speaking abilities while deepening word memory.

  • Create Language Environment: Integrate learned words into daily life to deepen impressions. Parents can put English labels around the house (like ‚Äúfridge‚Äù on the refrigerator) or use English words when seeing related items, allowing children contextual review. Play ‚ÄúI spy‚Äù games while walking, taking turns naming English words for objects seen. Help children understand that words are not learned just for dictation but are practical language tools.

  • Encouragement and Positive Feedback: During learning, parents should provide positive evaluation. When children spell a word correctly, immediately praise: ‚ÄúYou remembered so well! All these letter sequences are correct.‚Äù For misspelled words, avoid blame and say: ‚ÄúThis word is a bit difficult, shall we try again?‚Äù and point out key letters for attention. Allow children to first attempt phonetic spelling (even writing ‚Äúbkz‚Äù for because as phonetic spelling is acceptable), acknowledging their effort before gradually correcting. Warm encouragement builds children‚Äôs confidence and reduces dictation fear.

  • Assist in Creating Learning Tools: Parents can work with children to make word cards, word posters, or vocabulary notebooks. For example, create an ‚Äúerror word notebook‚Äù for easily confused words, writing mistakes in the notebook for future review and consolidation. Or use the previously mentioned ‚Äúposter word‚Äù method: draw a poster for each difficult word, collecting 5 ‚úîÔ∏ès means passing. Parents and children creating DIY learning tools together not only increases parent-child interaction but also makes children more willing to use these tools for self-assessment.

In summary, parental companionship should be in the role of guide and partner, helping children master words imperceptibly through reading together, playing together, and creating together. Creating a relaxed family learning atmosphere where children feel parental support and learning enjoyment is more effective than strict supervision.

V. Practice Activities and Games to Relieve Dictation Tension

Section titled ‚ÄúV. Practice Activities and Games to Relieve Dictation Tension‚Äù

Dictation tension often stems from fear of mistakes and unfamiliar testing atmospheres. We can design targeted practice and games to help children build confidence through simulation and overcome tension through fun.

By integrating spelling practice into games and interactions, such as having children spell words with letter blocks, we can create relaxed practice environments and reduce dictation pressure. Parental companionship and encouragement help children maintain pleasant moods during practice, improving memory effectiveness and confidence.

  • Role-playing Dictation: Parents and children switch roles, playing ‚Äúteacher and student‚Äù games. Have children be ‚Äúlittle teachers‚Äù giving parents word dictation tests. Parents intentionally misspell several words, asking the ‚Äúlittle teacher‚Äù to grade and score. Humorous role reversal helps children experience being the examiner rather than examinee, relaxing test tension. Meanwhile, grading reinforces words again. When children return to being students with parents as teachers simulating dictation, children feel more familiar and relaxed.

  • Timed Challenges: Sometimes tension comes from time pressure. We can design dictation practice as ‚Äúone-minute spelling challenges.‚Äù Parents set timers, saying as many learned words as possible within 1 minute, having children write quickly. This feels more like games than tests. After each challenge, count correctly spelled words and compete with previous personal scores. This personal challenge format makes children focus on surpassing themselves rather than fearing mistakes. As frequency increases, children discover their progress, building confidence.

  • Spelling Relay Ball: Prepare a soft ball for ‚Äúspelling ball toss‚Äù games. Parents first say a word and toss the ball to children, children state the word‚Äôs first letter then toss back to parents. Parents say the second letter and toss to children, continuing back and forth to spell out word letter sequences together. If someone says the wrong letter, it‚Äôs okay‚Äîjust restart that word. This moving-while-spelling practice turns dictation into cooperative games, with physical activity relieving tension. Playing with the whole family is more fun, memorizing spelling through laughter.

  • Error Word Elimination Game: Target several ‚Äúroadblock‚Äù words that particularly stress children during dictation by creating ‚Äúblast away error words‚Äù games. Write these words on separate small cards. Parents and children spread cards on the table like game levels. Parents act as quiz masters, saying the word meaning for children to write the English word. If correct, ‚Äúbang‚Äù stamp a small seal (representing bomb defusal); if wrong, don‚Äôt rush to correct but set the card aside to study together later why this word was wrong and how to remember it. Through this gamified checkpoint format, children feel achievement in defeating difficult problems rather than constant tension and fear when encountering them.

  • Relaxation Training: Teaching children simple relaxation techniques before formal dictation is also important. For example, deep breathing three times, quickly reviewing the word list to be dictated in mind, then telling themselves ‚ÄúI‚Äôm ready.‚Äù Parents can do a few seconds of eye exercises or shake hands to relax fingers with children, letting the body relax before writing. Also prepare an ‚Äúencouragement smile note‚Äù on the child‚Äôs desk with encouraging words or a smiley face drawing for children to look at before dictation, building positive mindset. Good psychological relaxation prevents nervousness and panic during tests.

Through these activities, children can gradually adapt to dictation formats through simulation and games, turning ‚Äútesting‚Äù into ‚Äúplaying.‚Äù When facing actual school dictation, they will associate with relaxed home practice scenes, maintaining calmer attitudes and performing at their proper level.

VI. Weekly Review and Testing Recommendations (Identifying and Filling Gaps)

Section titled ‚ÄúVI. Weekly Review and Testing Recommendations (Identifying and Filling Gaps)‚Äù

To truly master learned words, scientific review and testing mechanisms are crucial. Below are recommendations for review and consolidation in weekly cycles:

  • Regular Mini-Tests: Recommend that parents organize weekly mini-tests at weekend or beginning of next week, including new words from the current week plus repeatedly misspelled old words from previous weeks. Formats can vary: both formal written dictation and oral spelling or multiple choice. During tests, try to have children complete independently, then check answers together with parents. Regular testing serves as milestones, checking phased learning effectiveness and urging children to identify and fill gaps.

  • Error Word Notebook and Consolidation: Record misspelled words from each mini-test in an error word notebook. The error notebook can be a notebook or use sticky notes on a wall ‚Äúerror word wall.‚Äù At the beginning of the next week, spend 10 minutes with children specifically reviewing these easily misspelled words: analyze why they were wrong‚Äîmispronounced or confused letter sequences‚Äîand use previously introduced memory techniques to relearn targeting these issues. For example, if letters were carelessly omitted, create mnemonics for reminders. If certain letters are always written backwards, deliberately practice writing more to strengthen muscle memory. This ensures no omissions: weekly gap-filling prevents repeating the same word mistakes in next tests.

  • Cyclical Review (Spaced Repetition): Word memory requires repeated consolidation. Recommend adopting ‚Äúspaced repetition‚Äù strategies for review frequency. For example: new words learned on Monday, quick review on Tuesday (1-day interval), review again on Friday (4-day interval), review again next Monday (7-day interval). During each review, have children attempt eyes-closed spelling or listen to parents read words and write down to see if still remembered. If forgotten, focus on re-memorizing. Some practices show that through progressive consolidation at 1-day, 3-day, 1-week intervals, words transfer from short-term to long-term memory, becoming difficult to forget. Parents can help children create simple review schedules on calendars, marking which days to review which past words by intervals, making reviews planned.

  • Comprehensive Application Review: Besides mechanical spelling memorization, use reading and sentence creation to review words. On weekends, parents can read short stories or passages containing weekly words with children, consolidating vocabulary in context. If suitable materials aren‚Äôt available, have children use weekly learned words to each say or write a sentence. For example, if color words were learned this week, have children describe ‚ÄúMy favorite color‚Ä¶‚Äù Through comprehensive listening, speaking, reading, writing applications, check whether children truly understand word meanings and usage, not just spelling. Such reviews bring words to life and are more interesting.

  • Rewards and Achievement: After weekly reviews and tests, provide children positive feedback and rewards to strengthen achievement feelings. If children successfully master most words, draw progress bars beside vocabulary lists or paste small stars, visually showing ‚Äúmastered XX words this week.‚Äù If all pass, appropriately reward with watching an English animation episode or weekend outdoor activities. Help children feel they‚Äôve gained results after effort, motivating them for next week‚Äôs new vocabulary learning.

Through ‚Äúlearning‚Äîreview‚Äîtesting‚Äîfeedback‚Äù weekly closed loops, children can promptly discover and remedy vocabulary they haven‚Äôt mastered, gradually building more solid word banks. The gap-identification and filling process also cultivates self-monitoring and active learning habits. When children develop weekly autonomous review habits, future English learning becomes easier and more efficient.

Conclusion: This program emphasizes combining scientific memory methods with children‚Äôs interests, progressively improving vocabulary and dictation abilities. From controlling weekly word quantities and daily balanced training, to using visual association and fun mnemonics for word memorization, plus parental companionship and encouragement, and techniques for overcoming dictation tension, the aim is helping children learn meaningfully in relaxed, pleasant atmospheres. We hope through this program, children can gradually improve English word spelling levels, build confidence, and truly achieve joyful learning and good memorization, laying solid foundations for future English learning journeys. Wishing children happy challenges in the vocabulary kingdom with parental companionship, with new progress each week!

When teams share Claude accounts, each person‚Äôs requests are evenly distributed across different accounts, significantly reducing the risk of individual account bans.

  • OpenAI API Compatibility: Claude Relay Service provides both native Claude interfaces and OpenAI-compatible interfaces. This means you can call Claude using OpenAI API format! For example, by pointing third-party applications‚Äô API endpoints to http://<your-server>:3000/openai/claude/v1/, you can use Claude models just like calling OpenAI. This feature enables seamless integration of existing AI tools with Claude, eliminating the need to modify code for new interface compatibility.

  • Custom API Keys: For convenient team management, administrators can generate independent API Keys for each user. Team members access Claude Relay Service using their respective keys, while the relay service tracks request counts and token usage for each key. Administrators can set access permissions and rate limits, such as maximum requests per minute, monthly token quotas, or restrict which models are available. This approach allows teams to share Claude accounts while maintaining individual usage tracking and preventing resource conflicts, giving administrators clear visibility into each person‚Äôs usage patterns.

  • OAuth Quick Account Addition: Adding Claude accounts to the account pool is incredibly simple. Claude Relay Service integrates Anthropic‚Äôs OAuth authorization flow: administrators click ‚ÄúAdd Account‚Äù in the web interface, generate an authorization link, then log into their Claude account to authorize and integrate it into the service. The entire process requires no manual password entry ‚Äì secure and convenient. Note that if your server is located in regions with restricted access, completing OAuth authorization may require VPN assistance. With OAuth integration, even as teams add new members or change Claude accounts, administrators can complete configuration in minutes with seamless transitions.

These combined features create a secure, efficient, flexible, and controllable Claude sharing platform. For small teams unable to directly access Claude‚Äôs official service who want to share Claude subscription costs, this is undoubtedly a blessing! Claude Relay Service lets you avoid unstable third-party mirrors while maintaining control over your data and costs. As the official README states: data security, controllable performance, transparent costs ‚Äì the benefits of self-hosted services are clear at a glance.

Docker Compose Deployment Guide

Section titled ‚ÄúDocker Compose Deployment Guide‚Äù

Claude Relay Service offers multiple deployment options, with Docker Compose deployment being one of the simplest and most efficient choices. Let‚Äôs use Docker Compose as an example to build your Claude relay service from scratch.

1. Environment Preparation: Ensure your server has Docker and docker-compose tools installed. Since we‚Äôre using Docker containers, the operating system doesn‚Äôt matter much ‚Äì as long as it can run Docker. The official recommendation is to use overseas cloud servers (US nodes) for direct access to Anthropic‚Äôs Claude service. Before deployment, you‚Äôll need to register at least one Claude account and subscribe to the appropriate plan (teams typically choose Claude Pro or Max plans and split the costs). Additionally, prepare two security keys: JWT_SECRET and ENCRYPTION_KEY, used for JWT signing and sensitive data encryption respectively ‚Äì these must be random strings with sufficient length (32+ characters).

2. Get Project Image: The project provides pre-built Docker images that can be pulled directly:

The image supports both AMD64 and ARM64 architectures. Once pulled, we can run it using Docker Compose.

3. Write Configuration: Create a .env file in your deployment directory with the environment variables we prepared:

Above, JWT_SECRET and ENCRYPTION_KEY are required fields ‚Äì please replace them with your own random keys. ADMIN_USERNAME and ADMIN_PASSWORD are optional; if not set, the system will automatically generate default admin credentials on first startup and store them in the mounted data volume for reference.

Next, create the docker-compose.yml configuration file:

The Compose file above defines two services: claude-relay and redis. Let‚Äôs explain each field:

  • Images and Containers: The claude-relay service uses our pulled official image weishaw/claude-relay-service:latest, naming the container claude-relay-service for easy identification. The redis service uses the official redis:7-alpine lightweight image as the backend database. Both services have restart: unless-stopped set to ensure automatic restart on abnormal exits, guaranteeing high availability.

  • Network Ports: ports maps the container‚Äôs internal port 3000 to the host‚Äôs port 3000, meaning after startup you can access Claude Relay Service‚Äôs API and web management interface via http://<server-IP>:3000.

  • Environment Variables: environment lists the environment variables required by Claude Relay Service. ${JWT_SECRET} and ${ENCRYPTION_KEY} read corresponding values from our .env file. REDIS_HOST=redis specifies the service should connect to the container named redis as its database. ADMIN_USERNAME and ADMIN_PASSWORD use ${VAR:-} syntax, meaning if these variables are provided in .env, use those values; otherwise leave empty for automatic admin account creation. By centralizing configuration through environment variables, no sensitive information is hardcoded in images, and configuration changes are convenient.

  • Volume Mounting: Claude Relay Service writes logs and data to /app/logs and /app/data directories within the container respectively. We mount the host‚Äôs ./logs and ./data directories to corresponding container paths via volumes, achieving log and data persistence. This ensures that even if containers restart or upgrade, previous conversation content, account configurations, and other data won‚Äôt be lost.

  • Service Dependencies: depends_on: - redis indicates the Claude Relay service should wait for the Redis service to be ready before starting. This ensures the application can successfully connect to the database on startup without worrying about startup order issues.

  • Named Volumes: The volumes: redis_data: at the bottom defines a persistent volume for storing Redis data files. The Redis container mounts this to its /data path, allowing Redis data to be shared/persisted across containers.

With the configuration files ready, you can see they already cover admin account initialization, data persistence, built-in Redis, health restarts, and more. Docker Compose helps us handle all these deployment complexities in one go ‚Äì worry-free and effortless.

4. Start Services: In the directory containing the above files, execute:

Docker will pull the Redis image and start both containers. On first startup, Claude Relay Service will automatically initialize admin credentials. If we didn‚Äôt preset admin credentials in .env earlier, we can get the default account by checking logs or files:

The logs or files will display the admin username (typically defaults to cr_admin) and a randomly generated password. With admin credentials in hand, open http://<server-IP>:3000/web in your browser to access the web management interface. Enter the admin account to log in and start configuring your Claude Relay Service!

5. Add Claude Accounts: After logging into the admin backend, first integrate Claude official accounts into the system. In the ‚ÄúClaude Accounts‚Äù tab, click ‚ÄúAdd Account‚Äù, then click ‚ÄúGenerate Authorization Link‚Äù. The system will redirect to Anthropic‚Äôs official OAuth page, prompting you to log in and authorize. Use the Claude account you want to share to complete authorization, which will return an authorization code. Paste this back into Claude Relay Service‚Äôs add account page to successfully bind the account. The entire process is similar to using third-party apps to log into Google ‚Äì secure and convenient. Pro tip: If your server is in regions with restricted access, this step may require VPN assistance, otherwise you won‚Äôt be able to open Anthropic‚Äôs authorization page.

6. Distribute API Keys: With the account pool ready, you can create individual API Keys for team members. In the admin backend, go to the ‚ÄúAPI Keys‚Äù tab, click ‚ÄúCreate New Key‚Äù, name it (e.g., ‚ÄúZhang San‚Äôs Key‚Äù), then generate. You can also set permissions and quotas for that key during creation, such as maximum requests per minute, concurrency limits, available models, client binding, etc. After saving, the system generates a random API key string. Team members can then use this key to call Claude Relay Service‚Äôs API endpoints, and the relay service will query Claude on their behalf.

After completing these steps, a fully functional Claude team sharing relay service is successfully deployed! Wasn‚Äôt the entire process quite streamlined? With Docker Compose, we barely need to manually configure complex environments ‚Äì one command starts all services. The official team thoughtfully considered automatic initialization and data persistence in the Compose template, making it ready to use out of the box.

Best Practices

Section titled ‚ÄúBest Practices‚Äù

To maximize Claude Relay Service‚Äôs effectiveness in team collaboration, here are some lessons learned to share:

  • Smart Account Pool Planning: Use multiple Claude accounts to build your account pool, ensuring they have the same subscription tier (e.g., all Claude Pro/Max subscribers) so rotation won‚Äôt be hindered by individual account performance limitations. Account quantity can be adjusted based on team size and request frequency ‚Äì more people means more accounts for stability. Don‚Äôt worry about account idle time; as they say, ‚Äúmultiple Claude accounts on patrol means no fear of bans‚Äù ‚Äì even if individual accounts get temporarily suspended by risk controls, backup accounts can step in to maintain uninterrupted service.

  • Leverage Usage Statistics: Administrators should regularly check Claude Relay backend‚Äôs usage statistics to understand each API Key‚Äôs request volume and token consumption. This helps maintain transparent accounting within the team: when everyone splits Claude subscription costs, everyone has a clear ‚Äúunderstanding of the books.‚Äù If you notice abnormally high request volumes during certain periods, you can communicate promptly or adjust rate limits to prevent one person from ‚Äúmonopolizing‚Äù resources and affecting others.

  • Set Access Controls: Claude Relay Service supports rich usage restrictions for each API Key. Make good use of these features ‚Äì for example, limiting individual users to no more than N requests per minute, or allowing only specific clients/applications to use them ‚Äì to prevent misuse and abuse. Especially when opening access to more people or integrating with third-party applications, be sure to configure proper rate limiting and concurrency controls to protect backend Claude accounts from overload and prevent team conflicts over resource competition.

  • Monitor Network and Latency: Recommend deploying the service in regions with fast access to Claude servers (such as North America). If your team primarily uses it domestically, consider choosing relay routes friendly to domestic users. For example, deploy in the US but use optimized return networks to reduce latency during API calls. Based on practice, some domestic cloud providers‚Äô overseas machines may be blocked by Claude‚Äôs Cloudflare firewall, so pay attention to official channel announcements or community feedback.

  • Stay Updated: This project is very active with continuously improving features (such as recently added Claude-1.2 model support, etc.). Recommend regularly following the project‚Äôs GitHub homepage or Telegram announcement channels. Docker users can periodically docker pull to get the latest images, then restart services to upgrade. Staying current allows you to enjoy more stable performance and latest feature capabilities.

Final reminder: Using Claude Relay Service constitutes unofficial Claude API access ‚Äì please be sure to comply with Anthropic‚Äôs terms of service and avoid abuse that could risk your accounts. Self-hosted services give us greater freedom but also mean taking responsibility for security and compliance ourselves. Establish good usage guidelines within your team to ensure long-term ‚Äúhappy Claude usage‚Äù!

Conclusion

Section titled ‚ÄúConclusion‚Äù

With Claude Relay Service, we no longer need to rack our brains over team Claude account sharing. Whether you‚Äôre unable to directly access Claude due to regional restrictions or want to split the cost of expensive Claude Max subscriptions with teammates, this open-source project provides a flexible, reliable, secure, and private solution. We‚Äôve detailed its core features: multi-account pools, OpenAI interface compatibility, custom API keys, OAuth account addition, and more, showing you clearly how it meets team collaboration needs. At the same time, we‚Äôve demonstrated Docker Compose deployment step-by-step, from configuring environment variables to starting services ‚Äì we believe even readers who aren‚Äôt DevOps experts can follow along and quickly set up their own Claude relay station.

It‚Äôs easy to imagine that with Claude Relay Service, late-night coding sessions no longer fear Claude account quota depletion, and colleagues don‚Äôt need to each open separate accounts and pay duplicate fees. Everyone shares one ‚ÄúClaude resource pool,‚Äù taking what they need while keeping everything transparent and clear ‚Äì truly achieving cost savings and peace of mind!

item.title: Will Trae, Cursor, or Copilot Use My Code to Train Their Models?
item.content:encoded:
Yesterday, a post on V2EX went viral: the author discovered that Trae IDE continuously uploads code data, and even complaints on Discord were ‚Äúsilenced.‚Äù This revelation stirred up a hornet‚Äôs nest‚Äîdevelopers have only one burning question: Is my code actually safe?

1Ô∏è‚É£ Official Statements at a Glance

Section titled ‚Äú1Ô∏è‚É£ Official Statements at a Glance‚Äù
ToolUploads to CloudLong-term StorageUsed for Model TrainingCan Be Disabled
Trae (Domestic/Global)Yes, temporary uploads for indexing/chatPlain code deleted after processing, only embeddings retainedNo, official statement: ‚Äúwon‚Äôt train models except for computing embeddings‚ÄùNo privacy toggle
CursorYes, for completion & indexingMay retain by default; zero retention in Privacy ModeUsed for model improvement by default; no training in privacy modeHas privacy mode
GitHub CopilotYes, processed via AzureNo plain text saved, only for immediate inferenceNo training by default; personal users can opt-inManual training toggle available

Bottom Line: All three require ‚Äúuploads,‚Äù but Copilot and Trae officially claim they don‚Äôt train on code; Cursor requires manual privacy mode activation for ‚Äúzero training.‚Äù

üü¢ Trae: Official Promise of ‚ÄúEmbeddings Only‚Äù

  • Privacy policy clearly states: ‚ÄúWe do not use Your Content as training data for model training.‚Äù
  • Still sends code snippets to the cloud for vector indexing, deletes plain text, only retains embeddings.
  • Pain Point: No ‚Äúprivacy mode‚Äù like Cursor‚Äîusers can‚Äôt disable uploads.

üîµ Cursor: Only Truly Private with ‚ÄúPrivacy Mode‚Äù

Section titled ‚Äúüîµ Cursor: Only Truly Private with ‚ÄúPrivacy Mode‚Äù‚Äù
  • Collects telemetry by default for model improvement.

üü£ GitHub Copilot: Enterprise-Friendly, Personal Optional

  • Copilot Business/Enterprise: Code never used for model training.
  • Personal subscriptions: Also no training by default, with optional ‚ÄúImprove Copilot‚Äù toggle in settings.

3Ô∏è‚É£ Practical Advice for Developers

Section titled ‚Äú3Ô∏è‚É£ Practical Advice for Developers‚Äù
ScenarioRecommendation
Highly Confidential (Finance, Core Algorithms)Go offline. Use local LLMs or private cloud; disable any auto-completion.
Pure Open Source/Public ProjectsChoose Copilot or Cursor with minimal impact. Trae acceptable but requires accepting uploads.
Middle Ground (Partial Closed Source + Need Efficiency)Enable Cursor privacy mode or use Copilot; Trae currently lacks disable option‚Äîevaluate carefully.

4Ô∏è‚É£ Friendly Reminders for Tool Providers

Section titled ‚Äú4Ô∏è‚É£ Friendly Reminders for Tool Providers‚Äù
  • Make privacy mode the default, rather than making users dig through settings.
  • Publish transparency reports: What‚Äôs uploaded? How long is it stored? Is it actually deleted?
  • Granular controls: Indexing OK, training NO‚Äîlet users decide.

Conclusion

Section titled ‚ÄúConclusion‚Äù

No matter how sweet AI-assisted coding gets, remember:

Code is productivity, but also a risk vector.

Periodically review your tools‚Äô privacy policies‚Äîdon‚Äôt let silent updates quietly shift your security boundaries.

item.title: Hedge AI Risk: Why Internet Workers Should Hold Nvidia Instead of Worrying About Pay Cuts and Layoffs
item.content:encoded:
The internet era had near-zero marginal costs for ‚Äúinformation flow‚Äù; the AI era has persistently high marginal costs for ‚Äúinformation generation‚Äù that scale linearly with usage. Resources shift from ‚Äúpeople‚Äù to ‚Äúcomputing power + electricity,‚Äù as companies accelerate from light-asset tertiary industries toward ‚Äúsecondary industrialization.‚Äù As internet workers, we should upgrade our knowledge and skills with one hand, while using asset allocation (like Nvidia) to hedge the risk of dilution in the value chain with the other.

TL;DR

Section titled ‚ÄúTL;DR‚Äù
  1. Fundamental Change: PC/Mobile Internet = low marginal cost ‚Äúinformation distribution‚Äù; AI = high marginal cost ‚Äúinformation generation.‚Äù
  2. Company Profile: OPEX‚ÜíCAPEX, talent‚ÜíGPU, electricity, data centers, internet companies becoming ‚Äúindustrialized.‚Äù
  3. Personal Strategy: Career shifts from ‚Äúwriting features‚Äù to ‚Äúmanaging engineering and computing economics‚Äù; Assets use ‚ÄúAI upstream leaders + diversified ETFs‚Äù to hedge personal cash flow risk (not investment advice).

Recent Headlines

Section titled ‚ÄúRecent Headlines‚Äù

On July 2, 2025, according to WIRED magazine, Mark Zuckerberg offered top research talent compensation packages worth up to $300 million (approximately 21.8 billion RMB) over four years for his newly established Meta Super Intelligence Lab, with first-year total compensation exceeding $100 million (approximately 727 million RMB).

On July 11, 2025, Nvidia became the world‚Äôs first publicly traded company to exceed $4 trillion in market capitalization. Nvidia spent 30 years building a $1 trillion company, then took just two years to transform into a $4 trillion company.

On July 24, 2025, Google parent company Alphabet announced it would spend $85 billion in capital expenditures in 2025, up from the $75 billion indicated at the beginning of the year.

1. Three Fundamental Differences: PC/Mobile Internet vs. AI Era

Section titled ‚Äú1. Three Fundamental Differences: PC/Mobile Internet vs. AI Era‚Äù

‚ë† Information Method: From ‚ÄúInformation Flow‚Äù to ‚ÄúInformation Generation‚Äù

Section titled ‚Äú‚ë† Information Method: From ‚ÄúInformation Flow‚Äù to ‚ÄúInformation Generation‚Äù‚Äù
  • Past: The internet delivered existing content faster, broader, cheaper to users (search, social, video).
  • Present: AI regenerates text, images, code, speech, etc. for each user request, consuming computing power and electricity with every generation.

‚ë° Marginal Cost: From Near Zero to Persistently High

Section titled ‚Äú‚ë° Marginal Cost: From Near Zero to Persistently High‚Äù
  • Internet: Once network and CDN infrastructure is built, distribution marginal cost approaches zero.
  • AI: Training isn‚Äôt ‚Äúone-time,‚Äù requiring annual iterations + continuously increasing investment; inference is pay-per-call, higher usage means higher costs. Even if hardware iterations bring ‚Äúbetter performance at same price,‚Äù stronger models will consume the saved costs (trading experience for cost).

‚ë¢ Usage Scale: From ‚ÄúPopulation/Device Ceiling‚Äù to ‚ÄúUnlimited Automation‚Äù

Section titled ‚Äú‚ë¢ Usage Scale: From ‚ÄúPopulation/Device Ceiling‚Äù to ‚ÄúUnlimited Automation‚Äù‚Äù
  • Internet: Active users constrained by device and population ceilings.
  • AI: Agents/automation/autonomy remove ‚Äúhuman usage‚Äù limits ‚Äî machine-to-machine calls can amplify 7√ó24√óN times, with demand side having exponential growth potential.

2. New Profile of Internet Companies in the AI Era

Section titled ‚Äú2. New Profile of Internet Companies in the AI Era‚Äù

‚ë† Rising Capital Expenditure (CAPEX) with ‚ÄúAnnual Renewals‚Äù

Section titled ‚Äú‚ë† Rising Capital Expenditure (CAPEX) with ‚ÄúAnnual Renewals‚Äù‚Äù
  • Training: Large model infrastructure isn‚Äôt one-time, hardware depreciation cycles are short, replacing every 2-3 years.
  • Inference: Each call generates costs, revenue grows with usage, computing bills grow synchronously.
  • Financial Side: Shift from emphasizing OPEX (R&D salaries) to emphasizing CAPEX (GPUs, data centers, electricity).

‚ë° Resource Scarcity Reversal: From ‚ÄúEngineer Time‚Äù to ‚ÄúGPU + Electricity + Data Centers‚Äù

Section titled ‚Äú‚ë° Resource Scarcity Reversal: From ‚ÄúEngineer Time‚Äù to ‚ÄúGPU + Electricity + Data Centers‚Äù‚Äù
  • Internet era moats were network effects and near-zero distribution costs;
  • Current moats increasingly come from computing scale, power capacity, site selection and cooling, cluster scheduling and operational experience.

‚ë¢ Industry Attribute Switch: Tertiary Industry ‚Üí Secondary Industrialization

Section titled ‚Äú‚ë¢ Industry Attribute Switch: Tertiary Industry ‚Üí Secondary Industrialization‚Äù
  • Internet companies increasingly resemble traditional industrial enterprises: heavy assets, long cycles, strong maintenance, engineering-focused.
  • Talent Structure evolution: From large-scale SDE software development engineers ‚Üí Pre-training / Foundation Model and other ‚Äúcomputing management‚Äù roles.

3. Crisis and Opportunity in the AI Era

Section titled ‚Äú3. Crisis and Opportunity in the AI Era‚Äù

‚ë† Physical Constraints: GPUs and Electricity

Section titled ‚Äú‚ë† Physical Constraints: GPUs and Electricity‚Äù
  • Power capacity and grid access are hard constraints; data center differences in location, electricity prices, cooling determine unit computing costs.
  • Result: Computing expansion isn‚Äôt purely ‚Äúthrowing money,‚Äù but a systematic capability competition of ‚Äúengineering + supply chain + electricity.‚Äù

‚ë° Generation Excess: Strong Supply Side, Relatively Lagging Demand Side

Section titled ‚Äú‚ë° Generation Excess: Strong Supply Side, Relatively Lagging Demand Side‚Äù
  • AI capacity increases exponentially, but human attention and purchasing power don‚Äôt match, easily creating periodic ‚Äúbubbles.‚Äù
  • Solution: Let AI become ‚Äúconsumers‚Äù themselves ‚Äî automated agents complete retrieval, ordering, coordination processes, connecting supply to real business loops.

‚ë¢ Worker Reality: High-Benefit Era Contraction

Section titled ‚Äú‚ë¢ Worker Reality: High-Benefit Era Contraction‚Äù
  • Resources shift from ‚Äúpeople‚Äù to ‚Äúcomputing power,‚Äù SDEs‚Äô marginal bargaining power gets diluted.
  • Philosophy: Collaborate with AI in a friendly, polite, efficient manner, upgrade to ‚Äúengineering managers‚Äù (managing requirements, quality, data, costs, risks).

The AI wave won‚Äôt stop because of our fears.

Instead of worrying about salary cuts:

Improve your ability to ‚Äúorchestrate AI‚Äù rather than ‚Äúwrite business code‚Äù;

Include NVDA and other AI tech leaders in asset allocation, using stocks to hedge career risks;

Final note: How much of your salary would you convert to Nvidia? Why? Join the discussion in the comments.
